awd_titl_txt: Understanding Large-scale Zonal Jet Variability and Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the dynamics of the westerly wind belt of the mid latitudes of earth's atmosphere. The westerly wind belt is associated with the mid-latitude jet stream in the upper troposphere and it also influences the strength and position of fronts and mid-latitude storm systems. Despite the importance of the westerly jet on mid-latitude weather and climate, complex interactions between motions on a variety of different spatial and temporal scales makes understanding the important dynamical mechanisms controlling the strength and position of the mid-latitude jet very difficult. Progress has been made by separating the total flow into two components: 1) the background westerly flow, which is defined as the winds averaged in the east/west direction around the entire globe, and 2) the waves, which are defined as the difference between the total flow and the background flow. Recently, the PI has developed a methodology to separate the various mechanisms whereby the background westerly flow affects the waves. Because the role of the waves on the background flow is already well understood, this new methodology can be used to understand how the waves and the background flow interact to determine 1) the leading patterns of natural variability and 2) the response to external forcing, such as increasing greenhouse gases. 

This study extends previous work by applying the new methodology to state-of-the-art climate models and observations. This will determine the reasons for climate model biases in the mid-latitude circulation that will then help lead to model improvements and therefore more credible predictions of future climate change. For example, the natural variability of the mid-latitude jet is too persistent in time in climate models and moreover this bias has been shown to affect the magnitude of the response to increasing greenhouse gases. The new methodology is ideally suited to separate the proposed reasons for this bias: 1) the mean westerlies are too far equatorward in the climate models or, 2) the planetary wave activity is too weak in the climate models. In addition, the methodology is ideally suited to separate the proposed reasons for latitudinal shifts in the position of the westerlies in response to increased greenhouse gases.

Changes in simulated climate should be considered credible only to the extent that model spread is small. In this research, the reasons for the model spread in the westerly jet response and variability will be diagnosed so that the models can be improved. These improvements are important because increasing greenhouse gases tend to shift the position of the westerlies toward the poles. Furthermore, such latitudinal shifts in the position of the westerlies are a major component of the natural year-to-year variability in the mid-latitudes. For example, an extreme equatorward shift in the mid-latitude jet led to the extremely cold, snowy winter of 2009-2010 in the mid-latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere. A similar situation occurred in March 2013. Besides temperature and precipitation, these shifts in the westerlies also have many other impacts including poleward moisture transport, the earth radiation budget via cloudiness, the ocean circulation and sea ice. This project will have additional broader impacts because the PI is active in the climate impacts community. The PI's familiarity and access to climate model simulations through this and other projects enables him to provide essential information on the robustness of the climate information that these users need. In addition, after publication of the results, the code for the methodology used in this project will be made public on the PI's web site for other groups to diagnose and understand their own simulations and observations. This work will also train a Ph.D. graduate student.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the dynamics of the westerly wind belt of the mid-latitudes of earth?s atmosphere. The westerly wind belt is associated with the mid-latitude jet stream in the upper troposphere, and it also influences the strength and position of fronts and mid-latitude storm systems. Despite the importance of the westerly jet on weather and climate outside the tropics, complex interactions between motions on a variety of different spatial and temporal scales makes understanding the dynamical mechanisms controlling the strength and position of the mid-latitude jet very difficult. Such understanding is important for correcting biases in climate model simulations of the jet location, strength, variability, and the jet?s response to external forcing such as greenhouse gases.

 

In this project, various new model hierarchies, diagnostic methodologies and numerical experiments were developed to separate and understand the fundamental dynamical processes that control the large-scale zonal jets in the atmosphere and how these processes produce the response to external forcing (i.e. why do stronger jets shift poleward?), select the leading modes of internal variability (i.e. the annular mode), and lead to the poleward or equatorward propagation of zonal wind anomalies. Specifically, this project investigated 1) the atmospheric response to an array of different thermal perturbations by comparing an atmospheric General Circulation Model (GCM) and to a quasi-geostrophic model, which by definition has a simplified representation of the role of static stability (i.e. vertical temperature gradients) on the dynamics. These experiments enable one to separate the relative contributions of north-south temperature gradients versus static stability on the jet and storm track response to greenhouse-gas-like thermal perturbations. According to these experiments, the north-south temperature gradients make the largest contribution to jet response. In addition, these experiments suggest that the direct effect of static stability on baroclinic waves is usually less important than the effect of static stability on the mean overturning circulation. 2) In addition, multiple novel diagnostics were developed to separate the dynamical mechanisms that give rise to the positive feedback between annular mode jet anomalies and the waves embedded in the jet. This positive feedback controls the persistence of the annular mode. Because annular mode is too persistent in climate models, correcting the biases in the positive feedback will correct the biases in annular mode persistence. These new diagnostics show that the positive feedback primarily involves the latitudinal propagation of Rossby waves in the upper troposphere rather than the generation of Rossby waves via baroclinic instability in the lower troposphere. 3) This project has also developed a simple mechanistic model that reproduces wave?mean flow feedbacks that maintain the annular mode, cause stronger jets to shift poleward (and vice versa), and cause the poleward propagation of zonal wind anomalies. This simple model can be understood completely, and the contribution of various dynamical mechanisms can be cleanly separated. Applying the model to GCM output suggests that the reflection and absorption of latitudinally propagating Rossby waves are essential for the reproducing the observed jet behavior. The model also shows how the structure of the annular mode is related to the structure of the time-mean jet. 4) Finally, this project led to a novel understanding of a transient, negative feedback that affects all modes of jet variability.

 

The study of atmospheric jet dynamics from this project has important broader impacts because increasing greenhouse gases tend to shift the position of the jet and the westerlies toward the poles. In addition, such latitudinal shifts in the position of the jet are a major component of the natural year-to-year variability in the mid-latitudes. For example, an extreme equatorward shift in the mid-latitude jet led to the extremely cold, snowy winter of 2009-2010 in the mid-latitudes of the Northern Hemisphere. A similar situation occurred in March 2013. Besides temperature and precipitation, these shifts in the westerlies also have many other impacts including poleward moisture transport, the earth radiation budget via cloudiness, the ocean circulation and sea ice. This project will have additional broader impacts because the PI is active in the climate impacts and adaptation community. The PI?s familiarity and access to state-of-the-art climate model simulations through this project enables him to provide essential insight on the robustness of the climate information that these users need. This work also trained a graduate student.
